Question_Text: What personal data does the proctoring system collect?
Answer_A: Basic session recording only
Notes: Biometric data collection escalates privacy and bias risks

Question_Text: How does the system define suspicious behavior?
Answer_A: Pre-defined technical violations only
Notes: Behavioral interpretation carries high bias risk across all interaction levels

Question_Text: Has the system been tested for bias across student populations?
Answer_A: Extensively tested across all demographic groups
Answer_B: Basic testing on major demographic categories
Notes: Lack of bias testing with monitoring systems creates critical compound risks

Question_Text: How long is proctoring data stored?
Answer_A: Deleted within days of test completion
Notes: Long-term storage amplifies privacy and institutional risks

Question_Text: How does the AI adapt to diverse cultural contexts?
Answer_A: Uses diverse examples and cultural references
Answer_B: Adapts language but not cultural content
Notes: Cultural insensitivity compounds with other bias sources

Question_Text: How does the AI handle complex or controversial topics?
Answer_A: Presents multiple perspectives and encourages analysis
Answer_B: Gives balanced information with limited analysis
Notes: Loss of critical thinking opportunities has compounding effects over time

Question_Text: Can students understand how the AI makes suggestions?
Answer_A: Full explanation of AI reasoning provided
Notes: Opaque AI systems reduce learning effectiveness and trust

Question_Text: What level of help does the AI provide to students?
Answer_A: Hints and guided questions only
Notes: Direct answer provision creates dependency and skills degradation

Question_Text: What types of work will the AI evaluate?
Answer_A: Only objective clear right/wrong answers
Answer_D: All types including highly subjective work
Notes: AI assessment of subjective work carries high bias and accuracy risks

Question_Text: How does the system address potential grading bias?
Answer_A: Active bias monitoring and correction systems
Notes: Grading bias creates permanent impacts on student academic trajectories

Question_Text: Can students challenge AI grading decisions?
Answer_A: Full appeal process with human review
Notes: Lack of appeal rights concentrates power in opaque automated systems

Question_Text: How much do you rely on AI grading decisions?
Answer_A: AI provides suggestions only - teacher decides
Notes: Full automation leads to teacher deskilling and reduced professional judgment

Question_Text: How do you verify AI-generated content accuracy?
Answer_A: Comprehensive fact-checking of all content
Notes: Inaccurate educational content creates lasting knowledge gaps and misconceptions

Question_Text: Does AI-generated content include source attribution?
Answer_A: Always provides verifiable sources
Notes: Lack of source attribution undermines development of critical evaluation skills

Question_Text: How do you address potential bias in AI-generated materials?
Answer_A: Active monitoring for bias and stereotypes
Answer_B: Periodic review of content for bias
Notes: Biased educational content shapes long-term student perspectives and worldviews

Question_Text: Will students know when content is AI-generated?
Answer_A: Always clearly labeled as AI-generated
Notes: Hidden AI use undermines authentic educational relationships and critical thinking

Question_Text: How does personalization affect classroom community?
Answer_A: Maintains shared learning experiences
Notes: Loss of collaborative learning affects development of democratic participation skills

Question_Text: How does AI change the teacher's role?
Answer_A: Teacher remains primary instructor with AI assistance
Answer_B: Teacher and AI share instructional responsibilities
Answer_C: AI handles most instruction while teacher monitors
Answer_D: AI replaces most traditional teaching functions
Notes: AI replacement of teachers in vulnerable populations creates critical harm

Question_Text: How much control do students have over their learning path?
Answer_A: Students actively choose and direct learning
Answer_C: Limited student input on learning path
Notes: Loss of student agency over learning undermines educational autonomy and empowerment

Question_Text: How different will student learning experiences become?
Answer_A: Same core content for all at different paces
Answer_B: Some variation in approach and examples
Notes: Extreme individualization fragments shared knowledge base and democratic discourse

Question_Text: What aspects of student life does the system monitor?
Answer_A: Building access and safety events only
Notes: Comprehensive surveillance creates multiple simultaneous critical harms

Question_Text: Does the system try to predict future student behavior?
Answer_A: No predictive analysis - reactive only
Notes: Behavioral prediction systems create high bias risk and permanent stigmatization

Question_Text: Who has access to student monitoring data?
Answer_A: Strictly limited to essential personnel
Notes: Broad data sharing amplifies privacy violations and misuse potential

Question_Text: How long is student monitoring data retained?
Answer_A: Deleted within days unless incident occurs
Answer_C: Stored for multiple years for pattern analysis
Notes: Long-term retention of monitoring data creates permanent behavioral profiles
